author: sproul
content: you need a beacon node, it tells the execution node which blocks to process and what the head is

author: crisog
content: Ty

author: sproul
content: in future some execution nodes might incorporate beacon node light clients, but that's not ready yet (TM)

author: crisog
content: By any chance, do you know how to tell if an execution node (running an old client) did not upgrade, and differentiate it from an upgraded execution node?

author: sproul
content: currently (pre-merge) there's no difference between them, but once the merge happens in ~5h the unupgraded node will start following a different chain. on the merged node you can do`eth_getBlockByNumber finalized`, which won't exist on the non-merged node

content: Thanks

https://blog.bitmex.com/checking-ethereums-total-supply/

there's probably a quicker way to do this than 63 hours. I'm interested if anyone knows one

author: stevencook
content: so many statically defined counters

author: stevencook
content: for the merge to happen in 35 minutes, hashrate would need to be ~1450-1500Th

author: stevencook
content: using block # won't work either because as hashrate drops, difficulty drops, pushing block # out

content: 53 minutes seems impossible also

author: leeleettg
content: they keep resetting clock

author: stevencook
content: ah

author: stevencook
content:
for my estimate, with each block i do:
```
ttdTimeEstimate := tdLeft / dCurrent * averageBlockTime
```

author: stevencook
content: with `averageBlockTime` being `(blockNumLatest.timestamp - blockNumStart timestamp) / blockCount`

author: stevencook
content: with a variable to choose how many blocks max to go back (i default to 6500 but have started multiple counters today to identify hashrate drops that are more recent)

content: agreed.. while no new ETH is being mined, if you put yourself in the mindset of a mining operation, a wind-down of operations still needs to happen, including paying your electric bill that is probably coming in 30days.. divesting hw.. staff expenses.etc..... so I would expect a reverse s-curve in the amount of downward selling pressure from miners. and that might take weeks or months... but structurally there was a shift today and by all accounts all of the hard work made the merge look boring...

author: 0x1984
content: BTC is favored for stability. ETH focus on Utility. But I think Vitalik gets it right that ETH needs to finish Surge/Purge to boost chain capacity and performance before it can call major development done. Still after PoS (call it one time experience in life), I do not see any future planned hard forks of ETH pose noticeable risk for the chain as long as the same rigorous  testnet and shadow forking procedure can be enforced. In that regards, will BTC be truly much more stable going forward?

author: sky.cactus
content: No wallet I know of supports this, but you would have to research to see if that is the case.

author: schone_wizard
content: utility and elasticity can mean the same thing in this context, a financial token (be it coin, system, set of protocols) that can bend/mold/and contain the *changing* needs of its underlying users

author: schone_wizard
content: that's where the dollar fails today and why we see shortages of it, those who create it (banks) refuse to take risks (and you can't really blame them) and hence these downturns emerge where a world that uses a global currency is in dire need of it, but those in charge of making more of it available won't step up to the plate exactly because of said downturn and the risks it entails

author: schone_wizard
content: a vicious cycle

author: schone_wizard
content: can someone help me understand what is the EL's gossip used for now post merge? isn't the beacon chain driving the syncing of blocks and data pushing it into the EL client?

author: schone_wizard
content: is it just used to gossip mempool transactions?

author: ryanleeschneider
content: ya the mempool for sure, but I assume also pre-merge blocks are still available for syncing purposes.

author: pietjepuk
content: One question that I haven't seen come up yet, what is a safe low for priority fee (read: "correct compensation")  after the merge? It used to be determined based on uncle risk iirc, but... what is the uncle risk now?
